thread.title: Obama says Elizabeth Warren 'wrong' on trade
thread.title_full: Obama says Elizabeth Warren 'wrong' on trade

title: Obama says Elizabeth Warren 'wrong' on trade
text: Here's why the TPP is such a big deal 03:24 PLAY VIDEO Warren was referring to a U.S.-European Union trade partnership being negotiated with one of the issues being how much banks can borrow. E.U. officials have requested the U.S. lower the borrowing limits to what the Europeans have put in place, which so far American officials have refused to do. "This is hardly a hypothetical possibility," she said on Tuesday, because the U.S. is "already deep into negotiations" with the E.U. and "big banks on both sides of the Atlantic are gearing up to use that agreement to water-down financial regulations." RELATED: Obama sells trade deal to House Democrats When asked about how personal this fight has become, Obama said , "you know, the truth of the matter is that Elizabeth is a politician like everybody else, and she's got a voice that she wants to get out there. I understand that, and on most issues, she and I deeply agree. On this one, though, her arguments don't stand the test of fact and scrutiny. " Increasingly, the President has become more forceful against critics in his own party who are fighting against granting him this authority, telling an audience at Nike headquarters on Friday that there have been "a bunch of critics" against a proposed Pacific trade agreement and "typically they're my friends coming from my party." He said he has no other rationale than doing what he thinks is best for the American economy. "I actually think some of my dearest friends are wrong," he said. "They're just wrong."
